author: 0xraino
content: Just started onboarding to rayonism and have a noob question. Who cares about the effects of `setHead`? `assembleBlock` and `newBlock` already specify parents.

author: djrtwo
content:
sethead would help internal representations of state and block tree

you could theoretically keep the entire non-finalized block tree and associated state easily accessible but knowing the head is likely useful for a more optimal representation in the normal case of blocks being built on and added to the head

for example, geth constantly tries to keep a "pending" block around that extends the head with the current state of the tx pool. Set head would need to be used to make sure that any beacon chain re-orgs could be translated to the execution engine

also note that *unlike PoW* the eth2 pos fork choice is not only a funciton of the block tree. Thus you could have an entirely static block tree but get new info that had you reorg. So the newblock insert method is not entirely sufficient to knowing the head

author: djrtwo
content:
we discussed *not* having head to build on as part of `assembleBlock` and only being able to be built on head because there could be an implicit, temporary re-org due to the params of `assembleBlock`.

I really like this sethead requirement in a 1:1 architecture between consensus and beacon, but you could imagine this being limited in more diverse architectures, like a multiple beacons relying on a single execution engine.

tbh, I don't know if we need to optimize for such use cases. In such a case, you'd might not want `setHead` at all or at least restrict it to a single trusted beacon. or just have a super verbose and heavy execution engine that doesn't really have a notion of head and is ready to serve anything non-finalized

essentially, if someone wants to do an execution engine as a service, they can do the work to make it happen... and I'm not sure we should make it super easy anyway ðŸ˜…
